dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow is falling in a gusting wind. The voice of an old ma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sheriff of this county when I was twenty-five. Hard to believe. Grandfather was a lawman. Father too. Me and him was sheriff at the same time, him in Plano and me here. I think he was pretty proud of that. I know I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We dissolve to another West Texas landscape. Sun is risin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the old-time sheriffs never even wore a gun. A lot of folks find that hard to believe. Jim Scarborough never carried one. That's the younger Jim. Gaston Boykins wouldn't wear one. Up in Comanche County. We dissolve through more landscapes, bringing us to full day. None of them show people or human habitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always liked to hear about the old- timers. Never missed a chance to do so. Nigger Hoskins over in Bastrop County knowed everbody's phone number off by heart. You can't help but compare yourself against the old- timers. Can't help but wonder how they would've operated these times. There was this boy I sent to the gas chamber at Huntsville here a while back. My arrest and my testimony. He killed a fourteen-year-old girl. Papers said it was a crime of passion but he told me there wasn't any passion to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last landscape, hard sunbaked prairie, is surveyed in long slow pan. 2  VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told me that he'd been planning to kill somebody for about as long as he could remember. Said that if they turned him out he'd do it again. The pan has brought into frame the flashing light bars of police car stopped on the shoulder. A young sheriff's dep is opening the rear door on the far side of the car. VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said he knew he was going to hell. Be there in about fifteen minutes. I don't know what to make of that. I surely don't. Close on a pair of hands manacled behind someone's back. hand enters to take the prisoner by one arm. VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crime you see now, it's hard to even take its measure. It's not that I'm afraid of it. Back to the shot over the light bars: the deputy, with a hand on top of the prisoner's head to help him clear the door frame, eases the prisoner into the backseat. All we of the prisoner is his dark hair disappearing into the ca VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always knew you had to be willing to die to even do this job -- not to be glorious. But I don't want to push my chips forward and go out and meet something I don't understand. The deputy closes the back door. He opens the front passe door and reaches down for something-apparently heavy-at h feet. VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can say it's my job to fight it but I don't know what it is anymore. The deputy swings the heavy object into the front passeng seat. Matching inside the car: it looks like an oxygen ta with a petcock at the top and tubing running off it. VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...More than that, I don't want to know. A man would have to put his soul at hazard. The deputy slams the door. 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the door slam we cut to Texas highway racing under the lens, the landscape flat to the horizon. The siren whoops VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He would have to say, okay, I'll be part of this world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DEPUTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated in the sheriff's office, on the phone. The prisone stands in the background. Focus is too soft for us to see his features but his posture shows that his arms are stil behind his back.  DEPUTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir, just walked in the door. Sheriff he had some sort of a thing on him like one of them oxygen tanks for emphysema or somethin'. And a hose from it run down his sleeve... Behind him we see the prisoner seat himself on the floor without making a sound and scoot his manacled hands out u his legs. Hands in front of him now, he stands. DEPUTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well you got me, sir. You can see it when you get in... The prisoner approaches. As he nears the deputy's back he grows sharper but begins to crop out of the top of the fr DEPUTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yessir I got it covered. As the deputy reaches forward to hang up, the prisoner is raising his hands out of frame just behind him. The manac hands drop back into frame in front of the deputy's throa and jerk back and up. Wider: the prisoner's momentum brings both men crashing backward to the floor, face-up, deputy on top. The deputy reaches up to try to get his hands under the strangling chain. The prisoner brings pressure. His wrists whiten around th manacles. 4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deputy's legs writhe and stamp. He moves in a clumsy circle, crabbing around the pivot-point of the other man' back arched against the floor. The deputy's flailing legs kick over a wastebasket, send spinning the castored chair, slam at the desk. Blood creeps around the friction points where the cuffs b the prisoner's wrists. Blood is being spit by the deputy. The prisoner feels with his thumb at the deputy's neck an averts his own face. A yank of the chain ruptures the car artery. It jets blood. The blood hits the office wall, drumming hollowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prisoner walks in, runs the water, and puts his wrist now freed, under it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on the air tank. One hand, a towel wrapped at the w reaches in to hoist it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Road rushes under the lens. Point-of-view through a winds of taillights ahead, the only pair in sight. A siren bloop. The car pulls over. A four-door Ford sedan. The police car pulls over behind. The prisoner -- his name is Anton Chigurh -- gets out of police car and slings the tank over his shoulder. He walk up the road to the man cranking down his window, groping his wallet. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this about? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step out of the car please, sir. The motorist squints at the man with the strange apparatu MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? What is... 5  CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to step out of the car, sir. The man opens his door and emerges. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I... Chigurh reaches up to the man's forehead with the end of tube connected to the air tank. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you hold still please, sir. A hard pneumatic sound. The man flops back against the ca Blood trickles from a hole in the middle of his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh waits for the body to slide down the car and crum clearing the front door. He opens it and hoists the air t over into the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen through an extreme telephoto lens. Heat shimmer rise from the desert floor. A pan of the horizon discovers a distant herd of antelope The animals are grazing. Reverse on a man in blue jeans and cowboy boots sitting o his heels, elbows on knees, peering through a pair of binoculars. A heavy-barreled rifle is slung across his ba This is Moss. He lowers the binoculars, slowly unslings the rifle and l through its sight. The view through the sight swims for a moment to refind t herd. One animal is staring directly at us, its motion arrested as if it's heard or seen something. Close on Moss's eyes, one at the sight, the other closed. HE MUTTERS: MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold still. He opens the free eye and rolls his head off the sight to give himself stereo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on the hatch-marked range dial on the sight. Moss delicately thumbs it. 6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He eases the one eye back onto the sight. Point-of-view through the sight: Moss adjusts to bring th cross-hairs back down to the staring animal. Moss's finger tightens on the trigger. Shot: gunbuck swishes the point-of-view upward. Moss fights it back down. The point-of-view through the sight finds the beast again still staring at us. The sound of the gunshot rings out across the barial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short beat. The bullet hits the antelope: not a kill. The animal reco and runs, packing one leg. The other animals are off with it. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. He stands and jacks out the spent casing which jangles ag the rocks. He stoops for it and puts it in his shirt pock

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss is on foot, rifle again slung over his shoulder, binoculars around his neck. He is looking at the ground. An intermittent trail of blood. Moss's pace is brisk. Distances are long. He suddenly stops, staring. On the ground is the fresh trail of blood, the glistening drops already dry at the periphery. But this trail is cro by another trail of blood. Drier. Moss looks one way along this older trail: His point-of-view: flatlands. Scrub. No movement. He looks the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distant range of mountains. No movement. He stoops to examine the trail. 7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He paces it 'til he finds a print clear enough to give hi the animal's orientation. He stands and looks again toward the distant mountains. H brings up the binoculars. His point-of-view: landscape, swimming into focus, heat w exaggerated by the compression of the lens. Panning, looking for the animal. Movement, very distant. The animal is brought into focus: black tailless dog, huge head, limping badly, phantasmal virtue of the rippling heat waves and the silence. Moss lowers the glass. A moment of thought as he gazes of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and heads in the direction from which the dog ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss tops a rise. He scans the landscape below. Not much to see except-distant glints, off something not native to the environment. Moss brings up the binoculars. Parked vehicles: three of them, squat, Broncos or other o road trucks with fat tires, winches in the bed and racks roof lights. On the ground near the trucks dark shapes lie still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss is walking cautiously up to the site, unslung rifle the ready. Flies drone. He circles two dead bodies lying in the grass, covered wi blood. A gut-shot dog of the same kind we saw limping tow the mountains lies beside them. A sawed-off shotgun with pistol stock lies in the grass. The tires and most of the window glass are shot out of th first pickup Moss approaches. He opens the door and looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver is dead, leaning over the wheel. Moss shuts th door. 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door of the second truck. The driver, sitting upright, still in shoulder harness, i staring at him. Moss stumbles back, raising the rifle. The man does not move. The front of his shirt is covered with blood. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agua. Moss stares at him MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Agua. Por Dios. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't got no water. On the seat next to the man is an HK machine pistol. Moss looks at it. He looks back at the man. The man is still staring at him. Without lowering his eyes Moss reaches in and takes the pistol. Moss straightens up out of the truck and slings the rifle back over his shoulder. He snaps the clip off the machine pistol, checks it and snaps it back on. Moss crosses to the back of the truck and lifts the tarp that covers the truck bed. A load of brick-sized brown parcels each wrapped in plast He throws the tarp back over the load and crosses back to the open cab door. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agua. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I ain't got no agua. You speak English? A blank look. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Where's the last guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The injured man stares, unresponsive. Moss persists: 9  MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ultimo hombre. Last man standing, must've been one. Where'd he go? MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Agua. Moss turns to scan the horizon. He looks at the tire trac extending back from the truck. He thinks for a beat. MOSS (TO HIMSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I reckon I'd go out the way I came in... He starts off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the truck's open door: MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La puerta... Hay lobos... MOSS (WALKING OFF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't no lobos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss stops to look out at a new prospect. Flatland, no co He raises the binoculars. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you stopped... to watch your backtrack... you're gonna shoot my dumb ass. He doesn't see anything. He lowers the glass, thinking. He raises the glass again. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But. If you stopped... you stopped in shade. He sets off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POINT-OF-VIEW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the binoculars, some time later. One lone shelf o rock throws shade toward us. Heat shimmers in between. 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard sun makes the rock shadow impenetrable. But there is booted foot sticking into the sun toe-up like the nub on sundial. Moss lowers the binoculars. He looks at his watch. 11:30. He sits down. FAST FADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WATCH
Moss lowers the wristwatch and raises the binoculars agai The shadow has shifted. The foot hasn't moved. Moss gets up and walks toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss arrives at the rock shelf. The man's body is tipped to one side. His nose is in the dirt but his eyes are open, as if he is examining somethi quite small on the ground. One hand holds a .45 automatic. Next to the body is a boxy leather document case. Moss looks at the man. He takes the gun, looks at it, sti it in his belt. He drags the document case away from the body and opens i Bank-wrapped hundreds fill it. Each packet is stamped
Moss stares. He reaches in to rifle the stacks, either to confirm that the bag is full or to estimate the amount. He stands, looks around, looks back the way he came. 11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIS TRUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss's pickup is parked by a cattleguard off a paved but little-used road. Moss is just arriving. He throws in the document case, th rifle and the machine pistol, climbs into the cab and sla the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss's truck pulls into a trailer park that sits alongsid the highway on the outskirts of Sanderson, Texas. An old sign with a neon palm tree identifies the park as the Des Aire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss gets out of the truck next to a double-wide. Lights glow inside. He takes the case and machine pistol, gets d on his back next to the trailer and scoots underneath it. His point-of-view: plywood and plastic pipes. He pulls so insulation aside and crams the machine pistol up under th pipes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss enters carrying the document case. A twentysomething woman in cutoff jeans and a halter top watches TV. This i Carla Jean. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in the satchel? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's full a money. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be the day. Moss is crossing to a back bedroom. Before he disappears inside Carla Jean sees the pistol stuck in the back of hi waistband. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Where'd you get the pistol? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the gettin' place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He emerges without the case or the gun and crosses to the refrigerator. He takes a beer from the refrigerator and p its pulltab. 12   CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you buy that gun? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I found it. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Llewelyn! MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Quit hollerin'. He walks back sipping the beer and sprawls on the couch. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you give for that thing?  MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to know everthing, Carla Jean. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to know that. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep running that mouth I'm gonna take you in the back and screw you. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big talk. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just keep it up. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I don't wanna know. I don't even wanna know where you been all day. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are drifting down toward Moss as he lies in bed next t Carla Jean. He lies still, eyes closed, but he is shaking his head. As the camera stops he opens his eyes, grimacin MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the bedside clock. 13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its LED display: 1:06. He swings his legs off the bed, looks back at Carla Jean, and pulls the blanket up over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a gallon jug as Moss hold it under the tap, fill it with water. Carla Jean appears in the doorway, looking sleepy. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Llewelyn. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doin', baby? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goin' out. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goin' where? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somethin' I forgot to do. I'll be back. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you goin' to do? Moss turns from the sink, screwing the top onto the jug. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fixin' to do somethin' dumbern hell but I'm goin' anyways. He starts toward the front door. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...If I don't come back tell Mother I love her. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother's dead, Llewelyn. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then I'll tell her myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14  A MAP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A detailed topographical survey map, illuminated by a flashlight. Moss is studying it in the cab of his truck. After a beat he folds the map. He checks the .45 taken off the corpse with the money. Wider: the pickup truck parked outside the cattle guard. After a beat, the truck drives over the grate onto the un part of the road, jogging up the uneven terrain. Through the windshield, the view is pitch black except fo the boulders and scrub picked out by the crazily bouncing headlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOOR SLAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are close on the water jug slapping against Moss's leg we pull him through the darkness. The shape of his parked truck is just visible behind him, silhouetted on the cres by the glow of the moon already set. Walking across the basin to the near truck Moss freezes, NOTICING:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its driver's-side door: closed. Moss scans the horizon. Its only blemish remains his own pickup. He jogs the few remaining paces to the pickup. He sets do the gallon jug. Softly: MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?... No answer. He opens the door. The man's body is still held upright by the shoulder harn but his head, flayed by buckshot, is tipped away. Moss glances at the bed of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty. He again looks at the horizon. 15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now another pickup stands in silhouette next to his own. Two men are there. Moss covers behind the dead man's truck. He eases his hea out for another look. Only one man visible now. Sounds hard to identify. Something airy. Up on the crest pickup rocks and settles. Its tires are being slashed. The other pickup's engine coughs to life. Headlights and roof lights go on. Moss again covers behind the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A search-spot sweeps back and forth across the basin tabl of bodies and trucks. After a few trips back and forth something happens to the spot: its weaving light begins t bounce. We can hear the jouncing suspension of the pickup it trundles down the incline. But the light tells the perspective of the slowly approac truck. Moss stays in the lee of his sheltering vehicle as runs, doubled over, directly away from the light, keeping the shadow that wipes on and off. A gunshot. Its impact kicks up dirt just ahead of Moss to his right. Moss turns to see: Two jogging men flanking the truck like infantry escortin tank. One has just halted to fire; the other is now raisi his gun. Moss tacks and sprints and rolls under a second abandoned pickup to his left. Another shot sounds and misses. Bullets plunk into the metal of the truck body. One bulle skips off the dirt in front of the truck and pings up int the undercarriage. Moss is elbowing out the far side, next to a body lying b the truck's passenger door. The firing has stopped: Moss steals a look over the hood: The pursuing pickup is slowing so that the two gunmen can swing onto the running boards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck accelerates and as it veers around the first abandoned pickup its lights swing off Moss's cover truck. 16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss sprints off, doubled over, at a perpendicular to his previous path. He hits the ground, pressing himself into earth, head between his forearms. He elbows away as the truck bears on his former cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tops the small rise and straightens and flat-out runs. We hear the pickup's engine racing and see, behind Moss, spot sweeping backlight across the crest. Moss is running towards the declivity of a river gorge. S there is pink from unrisen sun. Moss bears on the gorge, panting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup bounces up into view on the crest behind him, roof lights blazing. It is pointed off at an angle. Its spotlight sweeps the river plain. It finds Moss. The truck reorients as it bounces down in pursuit. A muzzle flash precedes the dull whump of the shotgun. Moss races on toward the river. Another shotgun whump. Moss stumbles, turns to look behind him. The truck, gaining ground. A man stands up out of the sun one hand on top of the cab, the other holding a shotgun. Moss is almost to the steep riverbank. Another whump of t shotgun. Shot catches Moss on the right shoulder. It tears the bac of his shirt away and sends him over the crest of the riv bank. Moss airborne, ass over elbows, hits near the bottom of t sandy slope with a loud fhump. He rolls to a stop and looks up. We hear a skidding squeal and see dirt and dust float ove the lip of the ridge, thrown by the truck's hard stop. As Moss pulls off his boots we hear voices from the men i the truck. There is the clank of its tailgate being dropped and soun of activity on the hollow metal of its bed. 17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss tucks his boots into his belt and runs splashing int the fast-moving water. A look back: Something shakes the scrub down the steep slope. Moss backpedals deeper. Bursting out of the scrub at the foot of the slope: a hug black dog with a large head and clipped ears. It bounds t Moss. Moss turns and half stumbles, half dives into the river. Underwater a very dull whump followed by the fizz of buck Moss breaks the surface of the water, gasping, and looks BACK:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figures on the ridge. Below, the dog hitting the water. Another gunshot from the bank. Where it hits we don't kno River current and Moss's strokes speed him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sweeps around a bend. He finds his feet under him and staggers onto a sandbar and then splashes through some ou to the far bank. The pursuing dog's head bobs rhythmically in the water. Moss pulls the gun from his belt. He takes the clip out a ejects the chamber round. The dog finds his stumpy legs much closer to the sandbar: his massive head dips and waggles as he lurches out of hi swim. He emerges from the river and bounds across the san Moss shakes the gun and blows into the barrel. The dog splashes through the riverwash that separates him from the human. Moss reinserts the clip. He chambers a round as the dog r snarling and as the dog leaps he fires. Moss fires twice more quickly, not waiting to see whether the first round told. The dog lands, stopped but not dead. It jerks and gurgles MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamnit. He is looking out at the river. His boots are drifting by 18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss has climbed the far bank and found a seat on a rock. It is now full day. Moss has taken off his shirt and has neck craned round and his back upper arm twisted toward h Where the buckshot hit, his arm is purpled and pinpricked He meticulously picks shirt fiber out from where buckshot packed it into the flesh. He finishes. He rips swatches from his shirt. He starts wrapping his bare feet as he gazes off. His point-of-view: a lot of landscape, a highway in the distance. An eighteen-wheeler shimmies along in the heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At an isolated dusty crossroad. It is twilight. The Ford sedan that Chigurh stopped is parked alongside the pump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh stands at the counter across from the elderly proprietor. He holds up a bag of cashews. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much? PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty-nine cent. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This. And the gas. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all getting any rain up your way? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What way would that be? PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen you was from Dallas. Chigurh tears open the bag of cashews and pours a few int his hand. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What business is it of yours where I'm from, friendo?  PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean nothin' by it. 19  CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't mean nothin'. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just passin' the time. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that passes for manners in your cracker view of things. A beat. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well sir I apologize. If you don't wanna accept that I don't know what else I can do for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh stands chewing cashews, staring while the old man works the register and puts change on the counter. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Will there be somethin' else? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Will there? Beat. The proprietor turns and coughs. Chigurh stares. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is somethin' wrong? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With what? PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With anything? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you're asking me? Is there something wrong with anything? The proprietor looks at him, uncomfortable, looks away. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will there be anything else? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already asked me that.  PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I need to see about closin'. 20  CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See about closing. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time do you close? PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. We close now. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now is not a time. What time do you close. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Generally around dark. At dark. Chigurh stares, slowly chewing. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know what you're talking about, do you? PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said you don't know what you're talking about. Chigurh chews. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What time do you go to bed. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a bit deaf, aren't you? I said what time do you go to bed. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... A pause. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'd say around nine-thirty. Somewhere around nine-thirty. 21  CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could come back then. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you be comin' back? We'll be closed. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said that. He continues to stare, chewing. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I need to close now -- CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live in that house behind the store? PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've lived here all your life? A beat. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was my wife's father's place. Originally. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You married into it. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lived in Temple Texas for many years. Raised a family there. In Temple. We come out here about four years ago. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You married into it. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...If that's the way you wanna put it. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have some way to put it. That's the way it is. 22

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finishes the cashews and wads the packet and sets it o the counter where it begins to slowly unkink. The proprie eyes have tracked the packet. Chigurh's eyes stay on the proprietor. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What's the most you've ever lost on a coin toss? PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most. You ever lost. On a coin toss. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I couldn't say. Chigurh is digging in his pocket. A quarter: he tosses it He slaps it onto his forearm but keeps it covered. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call it. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call it? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just call it. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- we need to know what it is we're callin' for here. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to call it. I can't call it for you. It wouldn't be fair. It wouldn't even be right. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't put nothin' up. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you did. You been putting it up your whole life. You just didn't know it. You know what date is on this coin? 23   PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nineteen fifty-eight. It's been traveling twenty-two years to get here. And now it's here. And it's either heads or tails, and you have to say. Call it. A long beat. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look... I got to know what I stand to win.  CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stand to win everything. Call it. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Heads then. Chigurh takes his hand away from the coin and turns his a to look at it. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well done. He hands it across. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Don't put it in your pocket. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't put it in your pocket. It's your lucky quarter. PROPRIETOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Where you want me to put it? 24  CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anywhere not in your pocket. Or it'll get mixed in with the others and become just a coin. Which it is. He turns and goes. The proprietor watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is full night. Moss is pushing open the door to his trailer. We see Carl Jean inside. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Llewelyn? What the hell? Moss enters and the door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla Jean is finishing bandaging his arm. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odessa. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would we go to Odessa? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not we, you. Stay with your mother. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- how come? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now it's midnight Sunday. When the courthouse opens nine hours from now someone's gonna be callin in the vehi number off the inspection plate on my truck. And around n thirty they'll show up here. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... for how long do we have to... MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, at what point would you quit botherin' to look for your two million dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla Jean stares, thinking. 25  CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'm I supposed to tell Mama? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try standin' in the door and hollerin: Mama I'm home. CARLA JEAN LLEWELYN -- MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, pack your things. Anything you leave you ain't gonna see again. Carla Jean begins peevishly tossing things into a bag: CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well thanks for fallin' all over and apologizing. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things happened. I can't take 'em back.

dialogues.speaker: POINT-OF-VIEW THROUGH WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: It is night. No other vehicles on this paved road. Our car turns off and rattles over a cattleguard. Parked on the other side is a Ramcharger. Its passenger d starts to open. Outside: Chigurh emerges from his Ford. The man emerging from the truck wears a Western-cut suit. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind ridin' bitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE RAMCHARGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bouncing through ungraded terrain. It stops and discharges the three men-the driver and his partner, both in suits, from either side, and then Chigur from the middle seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have pulled over at Moss's truck. 26  CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This his truck? He is opening the door and looking at the plate riveted inside. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hm. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screwgie. The man reaches into a pocket and hands over a screwdrive As Chigurh works it under the plate: CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Who slashed his tires?  DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wudden us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flashlight beam picks out the dog carcass. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a dead dog. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Chigurh plays the flashlight around the scene. Dead bodie on the ground. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Where's the transponder? MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the truck. I'll get it. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are some ripe petunias. Chigurh gives his flashlight to the driver. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold this please. He bends down and takes a 9 mm. Glock off of one of the d bodies and checks the clip. The other man is returning fr the truck. He hands Chigurh a small electronic receiver.  CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You getting anything on this? 27   MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a bleep. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right... Chigurh stands and holds his hand out for his flashlight. The driver hands it to him. Chigurh shines it in his face and shoots him through the forehead. As the man falls Chi pans the light to the other man who has watched his partn drop. He looks up, puzzled, and is shot as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A horse trailer is backed up to a small stable with its g down. Sheriff Bell, sixties, in uniform, slaps a horse on the a and gives it a "Hyah!" to send it clattering up the ramp into the trailer. His wife, Loretta, appears. She wears a heavy robe and ho a coffee mug. LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was a car afire. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a car afire. But Wendell said there was something back country too. LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When is the county gonna start payin' a rental on my horse. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hyah! He is sending a second horse up into the trailer. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I love you more'n more, ever day. LORETTA (UNMOVED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very nice. Sheriff Bell puts up the gate and pins it. She watches.  LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Be careful. 28   BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always am. LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get hurt. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never do. LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hurt no one. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. If you say so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup with horse trailer rattles up next to a parked squad car. Just beyond the cattle guard the Ford sedan is blazing. Sheriff Bell gets out of the truck and joins his deputy, Wendell, looking at the car. After a beat of star BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't think a car would burn like that. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. We should a brought wieners. Sheriff Bell takes his hat off and mops his brow. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that look to you like about a '77 Ford, Wendell? WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say it is. Not a doubt in my mind. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old boy shot by the highway? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir, his vehicle. Man killed Lamar's deputy, took his car, killed someone on the highway, swapped for his car, and now here it is and he's swapped again for god knows what. 29  WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very linear Sheriff. Bell stares at the fire. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Old age flattens a man. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. But then there's this other. He nods up the ridge away from the highway. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. He walks back toward the trailer.  BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You ride Winston. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm more than sure. Anything happens to Loretta's horse I can tell you right now you don't wanna be the party that was aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men on horseback pick their way through the scrub approaching Moss's truck. Sheriff Bell is studying the gr BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the same tire tread comin back as goin'. Made about the same time. You can see the sipes real clear. Wendell is standing in the stirrups, looking up the ridge WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truck's just yonder. Somebodies pried the inspection plate off the door. Bell looks up, circling the truck. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this truck. Belongs to a feller named Moss.  WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Llewelyn Moss? 30   BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the boy. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You figure him for a dope runner? Bell sits his horse looking at the slashed tires. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know but I kindly doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE BODIES
dialogues.text: The two lawmen are dismounting.  WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell's bells, they even shot the dog. They walk towards the near truck. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well this is just a deal gone wrong. Sheriff Bell stoops to look at casings. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, appears to have been a glitch or two. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What calibers you got there, Sheriff? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine millimeter. Couple of .45 ACP's. He stands, looking at the truck. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Somebody unloaded on this thing with a shotgun. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm. Bell opens the door of the truck. Looks at the dead drive  WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...How come do you reckon the coyotes ain't been at 'em? 31   BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... He shuts the door softly with two hands. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Supposedly they won't eat a Mexican. Wendell is looking at the two corpses close together, wea suits. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These boys appear to be managerial. Bell walks back toward the bed of the truck as Wendell APPRAISES: WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I think we're lookin' at more'n one fracas. A gesture toward the scattered bodies. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Wild West over there... A nod down at the two men in suits with head wounds. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Execution here. Bell, at the back of the truck, wets a finger and runs it against the bed and looks at it. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Mexican brown dope. Wendell strolls among the bodies. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These boys is all swole up. So this was earlier: gettin set to trade. Then, whoa, differences... You know: might not of even been no money. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's possible. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't believe it. 32  BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Probably I don't. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a mess, ain't it Sheriff? Bell is remounting. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it ain't it'll do til a mess gets here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AIR TANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow it being toted along a gravel path and up three shallow steps to a trailer door. A hand rises to knock. Tubing runs out of the sleeve and into the fist clenched to knock. The door rattles under t knock. A short beat. The hand opens to press the nozzle at the end of the tube against the lock cylinder. A sharp report. INSIDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cylinder of brass from the door slams into the far wall denting it and drops to the floor and rolls. Reverse on the door. Daylight shows through the lock. The door swings slowly in and Chigurh, hard backlit, ente He sets the tank down by the door. He looks around. He ambles in. He opens a door. The bedroom, a messy aftermath of hasty packing. The main room. Mail is stacked on the counter that separa a kitchen area. Chigurh flips unhurriedly through the pieces. One of them a phone bill. He puts it in his pocket. He goes to the refrigerator. He opens it. He looks for a still beat. He decides. He reaches out a quart of milk. He goes to the main room sofa and sits. He pinches the spout open and drinks. 33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at himself in the dead gray-green screen of the facing television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh enters. Old plywood paneling, gunmetal desk, litt of papers. A window air-conditioner works hard. A fifty-year-old woman with a cast-iron hairdo sits behin the desk. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Llewelyn Moss.  WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you go up to his trailer? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I did. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'd say he's at work. Do you want to leave a message? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does he work? WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does he work? WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir I ain't at liberty to give out no information about our residents. Chigurh looks around the office. He looks at the woman. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does he work? WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you not hear me? We can't give out no information. A toilet flushes somewhere. A door unlatches. Footsteps i back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh reacts to the noise. He looks at the woman. He tu and opens the door and leaves. 34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the passengers are getting out. Moss is up in the aisle reaching a bag down from the overhead rack. He lift the document case from the floor where Carla Jean still s next to the window. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why all the way to Del Rio? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna borrow a car. From Eldon. Carla Jean nods at the document case. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't afford one? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't wanna register it. I'll call you in a couple days. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a bad feelin', Llewelyn. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I got a good one. So they ought to even out. Quit worrying about everthing. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama's gonna raise hell. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is just gonna cuss you up'n down. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be used to that. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm used to lots of things, I work at Wal-Mart. 35  MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not any more, Carla Jean. You're retired. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Llewelyn? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am? CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are comin back, ain't ya? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendell is knocking at its door. Sheriff Bell stands one step behind him. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff's Department! No answer. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the lock. They both look. A beat. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We goin' in? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gun out and up. Wendell unholsters his gun but hesitates. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about yours? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hidin' behind you. Wendell eases the door open. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff's Department!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men cautiously enter, Wendell leading. 36  WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Nobody here. He lowers his gun and starts to holster it. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reason not to stay safe. Wendell keeps the gun out. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. He goes to the bedroom door as Sheriff Bell, seeing the l cylinder on the floor, stoops and hefts it. He looks up at the wall opposite the door: the small dent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendell pulls his head out of the bedroom. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I believe they've done lit a shuck. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe you're right. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That from the lock? Sheriff Bell stands and wanders, looking around. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably must be. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when was he here? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Oh. He is at the counter staring at something. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Now that's aggravating. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff? Sheriff Bell points at the carton of milk. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still sweating. Wendell is agitated. 37   WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Sheriff! Sheriff Bell unhurriedly opens a cabinet. He looks closes it, opens another. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sheriff, we just missed him! We gotta circulate this! On the radio! Sheriff Bell takes a glass from the cabinet. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, okay... He pours milk into the glass.  BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What do we circulate? He sits on the sofa and takes a sip from the milk. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Lookin' for a man who has recently drunk milk? Wendell stares at him. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff, that's aggravating. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ahead of you there. Wendell gazes around the trailer, shaking his head. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think this boy Moss has got any notion of the sorts of sons of bitches that are huntin' him? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He ought to... Sheriff Bell takes another sip. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He seen the same things I seen and it made an impression on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss emerges from the station and goes to a cab. 38

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he sits in: MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me to a motel. CABBIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got one in mind? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just someplace cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RATE CARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rates for Charlie Goodnight's Del Rio Motor Court are under its address of Highway 84 East and an ovalled AAA l Single Person $24.00 Double Bed/Couple $27.00 2 Double Bed/Couple $28.00 2 Double Bed/3 People $32.00 Voices play off: WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me the option. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The what? WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The option. Wider shows that we are in a motel lobby. A woman faces M across a Formica counter top She has handed him the frame rate card. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You pick the option with the applicable rate. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just one person. Don't matter the size of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide on the room. Twin-bed headboards are fixed to the wa but only the far one has a bed parked beneath it. Moss si on the bed, phone to his ear. It rings a couple times. He gives up, hangs up, rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss stands in front of the mirror, twisted around to exa the buckshot wound. He shrugs his shirt back on. Holding on the mirror we see him walk back into the main room and stop, looking around. He looks slowly up to the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: A SCREW
dialogues.text: Being unscrewed. Wider shows us Moss, standing on the bed unscrewing the vent on an overhead airduct. He gets down off the bed, unzips his duffle bag and takes the document case out of it. He opens the case, takes out packet of bills, counts out some money and puts it in his pocket. He refastens the case. He goes to the window and cuts off a length of the curtai cord. He ties the curtain cord to the handle of the docum case. He goes to the closet, leaving the case on the bed. He reaches into the empty closet, lifts the coat rail off its supports and lets the hangers slide off onto the floo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The duct hums with a low, airy compressor sound. The galvanized metal stretches away to a distant elbow. The document case is plunked down in the foreground and then gently pushed down the length of the tube by the coat pol The free end of the cord trails off the handle for retrie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DUFFLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss unzips it and pulls out the machine pistol and the . that he took off the dead man. He lifts the mattress and stashes the machine pistol underneath. He checks the cham of the .45 and stuffs it in his belt. 40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WINDOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss pulls back one curtain to look out at the lot. Nothing there disturbs him. He closes the curtains, crossing one over the other. He goes out the door, shutting it softly behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHONE BILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pencil taps at a Del Rio number that repeats on the bil We hear phone-filtered rings. The rings are cut off by the clatter of a hang-up. The pe moves to an Odessa number, the only other repeat on the s list of toll calls. We cut up to Chigurh as he finishes dialing, in the booth a roadside diner. Dusk. Phone-filtered rings. Connection; a woman's voice: WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Llewelyn there? WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Llewelyn?! No he ain't. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expect him? The woman's voice is old, querulous: WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now why would I expect him? Who is this? Chigurh stares for a short beat, then prongs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss is standing in front of a rack of cowboy boots at th back of the store. He looks up at an approaching salesman bow-legged old man in a white shirt. 41  SALESMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hep you? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need the Larry Mahan's in black, size 11. SALESMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sell socks? SALESMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just white. He gathers up a brown paper bag from a pharmacy.  MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White is all I wear. You got a bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss is sitting on the toilet taking off socks with blood soles. Sneakers sit on the floor. The pharmacy bag sits n to them. He sprays disinfectant on his feet. He takes out bandages

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss is returning. The bowlegged salesman stands in the a holding aloft a pair of boots. SALESMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't got Larries in black but I got 'em in osta-rich. Break in easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is rolling to a stop in front of Charlie Goodnight's D Rio Motor Hotel. Moss fishes for his wallet but stops, looking. Parked in the street in front of the motel is an offroad truck with roof lights. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't stop. Just ride me up past the rooms. 42  DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What room? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just drive me around. I want to see if someone's here. The cab rolls slowly up the lot. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Keep going. His pivoting point-of-view of his room. The window shows part between the curtains. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Keep going. Don't stop.  DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to get in some kind of a jackpot here, buddy. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't I set you down here and we won't argue about it. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to take me to another motel. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just call it square. Moss reaches a hundred-dollar bill up to the driver. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're already in a jackpot. I'm trying to get you out of it. Now take me to a motel. The driver reaches up for the bill then turns the cab out the parking lot onto the hiway. Moss turns to look at the receding lights of the motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAVEMENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rushing under the lens, lit by headlights. 43

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From high up we see a throughway interchange as Chigurh's Ramcharger takes the right fork of the highway under a gr sign for Del Rio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh looks down at the passenger seat. On it lies the transponder, powered on but silent. Next to it is a machi pistol with a can-shaped silencer sweated onto the barrel The transponder beeps once. Chigurh looks up. We are approaching a steel bridge. The headlights pick up a large black bird perched on the alum bridge rail. The passenger window hums down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh picks up the pistol and levels the barrel across window frame. The truck bumps onto the bridge, its tires skipping over seams in the asphalt. As it draws even the bird spreads i wings and Chigurh fires-a muted thump like a whoosh of ai From high overhead: the bullet hits the guardrail making hum as the Ramcharger recedes and the bird lifts into the darkness, heavily flapping its wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning. Bell sits drinking coffee. Wendell stands in the aisle handing something over. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He labs from Austin on the man by the highway. Bell takes the papers and starts to look at them. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was the bullet? WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't no bullet. This brings Bell's look up. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't no bullet?  WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. Wasn't none. 44  BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Wendell, with all due respect, that don't make a whole lot of sense. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said entrance wound in the forehead, no exit wound. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you telling me he shot this boy in the head and then went fishin' around in there with a pocket knife? WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I don't want to picture that. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't either! A beat during which both men picture it, ended by an arri waitress. WAITRESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I freshen that there for you Sheriff? The Sheriff's distressed look swings on to her. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes Noreen you better had. Thank you. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rangers and DEA are heading out to the desert this morning. You gonna join 'em? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Any new bodies accumulated out there? WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then I guess I can skip it. Heavens to Betsy, Wendell, you already put me off my breakfast. 45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss pushes off from the wall he was leaning against: som inside the glass double doors is stooping to unlock them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk is handing a shotgun across the counter. CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve gauge. You need shells? Moss looks the gun over. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Double ought.  CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll give you a wallop. He pushes the shells across. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have camping supplies? ANOTHER COUNTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clerk stares at Moss. CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tent poles. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already have the tent? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somethin' like that. CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you give me the model number of the tent I can order you the poles. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. I want a tent. CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of tent?  MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kind with the most poles. 46  CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I guess that'd be our ten-foot backyard Per-Gola. You can stand up in it. Well, some people could stand up in it. Six foot clearance at the ridge. You might just could. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me have that one. Where's the nearest hardware store?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has the shotgun wedged in an open drawer and is sawing off its barrel with a hacksaw. MINUTES LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss sits on the bed dressing the barrel with a file. He puts down the file, looks at the barrel. He slides the forearm back and forward again and lets the hammer down w his thumb. He looks the gun over, appraising, and then op the box of shells and starts feeding in the heavy waxed l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss enters carrying a new duffle bag. The same woman is behind the counter. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I get another room. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to change rooms? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I want to keep my room, and get another one. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another additional. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.You got a map of the rooms? She inclines her head to look under the counter. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah we had a sorta one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finds a brochure and hands it across. It shows a car from the fifties parked in front of the hotel in hard sunlight. 47

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss unfolds the brochure and studies. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about one forty-two. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have the one next to yours if you want. One twenty. It ain't took. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, one forty-two. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's got two double beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An arcing point of view on the window of Moss's old room. The curtain still slightly open. A reverse shows Moss crossing the lot from the office car his long nylon duffle bag, studying the room. He looks further down the street. The truck with the roof lights is still parked there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two double beds. Moss is listening at the wall. He goes t the bed and unzips the duffle bag and pulls out the sawed off shotgun. He lays it on the bed. He pulls the tent pol and some duct tape out of the duffle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving slowly down the street with frequent glances down the receiver on the seat next to him. The receiver lights ups and bleeps one time. Chigurh slows and looks around at the buildings that line the two-lane highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss is standing on a desk chair unscrewing the plate fro the overhead airduct. He lays it aside and raises a flash and peers into the airduct. 48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the length of the duct we see an elbow junction ten feet away. The end of the document case is just visible sticking out into the elbow. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The receiver is bleeping slowly as the car creeps along. at a distant intersection is Charlie Goodnight's Del Rio Motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss rips off a length of duct tape. He wraps it around t tent poles placed end-to-end but an inch apart, not butti He gives the tape several winds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is slowly driving the parking lot, the receiver now in his lap. The beeping frequency peaks and then starts to fall off. Chigurh puts the truck in reverse and eases back to the p His point-of-view: window with parted curtains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss experiments with the tape-joint, angling then straightening the two poles. Satisfied, he starts taping a third length of pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh stands across the counter from the clerk who look at him, waiting. He is frowning at the rate card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It swings slowly in toward us. Chigurh stands in the door The room-number bangle hangs off the key in the knob. He stares in for a beat. 49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters slowly and reaches up for the light switch. He doesn't turn it on. He drops his hand. He reaches up agai feeling it. He looks around the room. He takes the key and closes the door behind him. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss pulls three wire hangers off the closet rack. He tak them to the bureau and picks up a sidecutter. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks over to the bathroom. He turns on its light, looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves the door open. He goes to a closet, opens it, l He goes to the door of the room but doesn't open it. He s with his back against it and looks at the room. The bathroom door. The closet door. Chigurh goes to the bed and sits to take off his boots. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss snips the last of the wire hangers' hooks off with t sidecutter. He wraps the three hooks with duct tape to ma a sturdier one. He wraps more tape to attach this hook to the end of the three-link pole. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a bag he withdraws a twelve-gauge automatic shotgun fitted with a silencer big around as a beer can. He checks the loads. He picks up the regularly beeping receiver, turns it off, and slips it into his pocket. He hoists the air tank. 50  MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is standing on the chair below the airduct, stooping t pick up the jury-rigged pole leaning nearby. He straighte and feeds the length of the pole into the duct, using the joints to angle it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the duct: he watches the pole play in, illuminated the flashlight he has left resting inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STOCKINGED FEET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We track on the feet padding down the exterior walkway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peering along the airduct, both hands up next to one ear awkwardly maneuvering the pole. He lays the far, hooked end over the protruding corner of the document case. He pulls. The pole slides off the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands at the door of Moss's first room. He eases an e against it. He steps back. He punches out the lock cylinder with the airgun and kick in the door, raising the shotgun. A Mexican in a guyabera reclines on one of the two double beds. He is scrabbling for a machine pistol on the nightstand. Chigurh fires three times quickly. The damped blasts have the low resonance of chugs into a bottle. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Head still in the airduct, frozen, listening. 51

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also frozen, back against the wall outside the room, to o side of the open door. After a beat he steps back into the open doorway leveling the gun. Inside the room: no movement. Much of the man on the bed spattered against the chewed-up headboard. The bathroom door is ajar, its light on. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Movement in the wedge of light. Immediately, chugs from the shotgun chew up bathroom door and nearby wallboard. A cry from inside. A brief chatter of machine pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOSS'S POV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along the air vent. The machine-pistol chatter crosses the cut. We hear bullets snap through metal. The sound brings on indirect light as holes are punched in the duct somewhere around the bend. Moss holds still as the galvanized metal faintly thunders The flashlight resting on it wobbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gun leveled, at the open door. Again, no movement. He advances into the room, gun pointing at the bathroom d As he advances he swings the gun briefly over at the clos door and fires. The splintered-in door reveals no occupan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh angles around the double bed to get a view of tha wedge of bathroom floor visible through its door. Blood i pooling out from the right. 52

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh fires at the baseboard to the right of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss makes another attempt to hook the bag. The hook take Moss drags the case inches out into the duct's bend befor the hook slides off again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He uses the shotgun barrel to push open what's left of th bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mirror over the facing sink gives a view of most of t hidden side of the bedroom/ bathroom party wall. Partial view of a man pressed against the wall, standing in the t in the corner. From his posture and the one visible hand seems unarmed. Chigurh enters the bathroom. The cornered man is unhurt but terrified. He holds up his hands. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No me mate. The man on the floor is quite dead. A machine pistol lies one out-flung hand. Chigurh looks back up at the survivor. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you find it? MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No me mate. Chigurh walks unhurriedly to the tub. The man watches him hands up, vibrating. Chigurh reaches with his free hand and pulls the shower curtain most of the way round, hiding the man. He angles nose of the shotgun in and fires. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hook again snags a strap on the case. Moss pulls, carefully. 53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh emerges from the bathroom. His socks are sodden w gore. He sits on the bed and peels them off. He rubs the bottom of each foot with the ankle of each sock and drops the socks to the floor. He rises and opens three bureau drawers, which are empty, and leaves them open. He pulls open what remains of the closet door. Empty. He looks under the bed. He stands, looks around. He looks up. His look lingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on the airduct grille: it is dusty. Rub-marks have made four dark bands across the dusty slats. Chigurh's fi rise into frame and meet the grille, roughly aligning wit the finger marks in the dust. Close on a screwhead: a dime enters and engages the screw and starts turning it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From inside the duct: fingers reach through the grille an Chigurh's hand pushes it up into the duct, then angles it and withdraws it. Faintly, under the distant airy drone o the compressor, we hear the grate clatter to the floor. The back of Chigurh's head appears. He aims a flashlight away down the far length of the duct. A beat. He pivots to face us. His point-of-view: the length of the duct, empty, with a drag-mark through the middle of the dust. Back to Chigurh. His look holds. He ducks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the room: Chigurh steps down from the chair and pulls receiver from his pocket and turns it on. It beeps once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. 54

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frowning, looking down at the receiver, Chigurh makes a s sweep with it. The silence holds-snapped off by car stead as we cut to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss, with his duffle bag and document case, sits in the passenger seat of an old station wagon. The driver is an elderly man in a yoked shirt. After a beat, eyes fixed on the road, the old man shakes head. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't be doin' that. Even a young man like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss gives him a look. A beat. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doin' what. The old man gazes at the road. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchhikin'. He shakes his head again. Silent driving. The old man mur OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOMING UP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking out as a foreground building slips by and rise to get an ever-higher perspective on downtown Housto hazy under a noon sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man standing behind a large desk-behind him, floor-to- ceiling windows-has no small talk for Carson Wells, the m entering. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Anton Chigurh by sight, is that correct? Carson Wells sits in front of the desk, his manner affabl He rests a booted foot across one knee. 55  WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir, that's correct. I know 'em when I see 'em. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you last see him. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: November the 28th, last year. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem pretty sure of the date. Did I ask you to sit? WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir but you struck me as a man who wouldn't want to waste a chair. I remember dates. Names. Numbers. I saw him on November 28th. The man gazes. He nods. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a loose cannon here. And we're out a bunch of money, and the other party is out his product. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. I understand that. The man looks at him, appraising. He nods again and slide bank card across the table. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This account will only give up twelve hundred dollars in any twenty-four hour period. That's up from a thousand. Wells rises to take the card and then reseats himself. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your expenses run higher I hope you'll trust us for it. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How well do you know Chigurh. 56  WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well enough. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not an answer. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to know? MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd just like to know your opinion of him. In general. Just how dangerous is he? Wells shrugs. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
