dialogues.text: Compared to what? The bubonic plague? He's bad enough that you called me. He's a psychopathic killer but so what? There's plenty of them around. A beat. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He killed three men in a motel in Del Rio yesterday. And two others at that colossal goatfuck out in the desert. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. We can stop that. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem pretty sure of yourself. You've led something of a charmed life haven't you Mr. Wells? Wells rises. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In all honesty I can't say that charm has had a whole lot to do with it. He thumps once at his chest. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm wondering... MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?  WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get my parking ticket validated? 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man gazes. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...An attempt at humor, I suppose. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mr. Wells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss is getting out of the station wagon with his duffle document case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a town square. Among the old buildings is the Hotel Eagle, identified by a neon above the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss enters. Behind the front desk an older man sits read Ring magazine. He has a hand-rolled cigarette. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One room, one night. CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's twenty-six dollars. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You on all night? CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir, be here til ten tomorrow morning. Moss pushes a hundred along with smaller bills across the desk. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you. I ain't asking you to do anything illegal. The clerk looks at the hundred-dollar bill without reachi CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waitin' to hear your description of that. 58  MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's somebody lookin' for me. Not police. Just call me if anyone else checks in tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss is mounting the stairs from the lobby. The carpeted hallway is lined by transom-topped doors. Moss goes to a door halfway down on his left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss enters a room with old oak furniture and high ceilin He sets the document case next to the bed. He unzips the duffel and takes out the shotgun which he l on the bed, and then goes to the window. He parts the cur to look down. The street is empty. Mexican music floats up faintly from bar somewhere not far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dark. The music is gone. We are looking straight down on Moss lying, clothed, on t bed. We are booming straight down toward him. After a beat he shakes his head. He opens his eyes, grimacing. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There just ain't no way. He sits up and turns on the bedside lamp. The shot gun and document case are on the floor by the be Moss swings the document case onto the bed and unclasps i and upends the money onto the bed. He feels the bottom of the case, squeezing it with one hand inside and one hand out, looking for a false bottom. He eyeballs the case, tu it over and around. He starts riffling money packets. He finds one that binds. It has hundreds on the outside b ones inside with the centers cut out. In the hollow is a sending unit the size of a Zippo lighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds the sender, staring at it. A long beat. 59

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From somewhere, a dull chug. The sound is hard to read-a compressor going on, a door thud, maybe something else. The sound has brought Moss's look up. He sits listening. further sound. Moss reaches to uncradle the rotary phone by the bed. He dials 0. We hear ringing filtered through the handset. Also, faint offset, we hear the ring direct from downstairs. After five rings Moss cradles the phone. He goes to the door, reaches for the knob, but hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets down on his hands and knees and listens at the cr under the door. An open airy sound like a seashell put to your ear. Moss rises and turns to the bed. He piles money back into the document case but freezes suddenly-for no reason we c see. A long beat on his motionless back. We gradually become a of a faint high-frequency beeping, barely audible. Its so is indeterminate. Moss clasps the document case, picks up his shotgun and e himself to a sitting position on the bed, facing the door He looks at the line of light under it. The beeps approach, though still not loud. A long wait. At length a soft shadow appears in the line of light belo the door. It lingers there. The beeping-stops. A beat. Now the soft shadow becomes more focused. It reso into two columns of dark: feet planted before the door. Moss raises his shotgun toward the door. A long beat. Moss adjusts his grip on the shotgun and his finger tight on the trigger. The shadow moves, unhurriedly, rightward. The band of lig beneath the door is once again unshadowed. Quiet. Moss stares. 60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band of light under the door. Moss stares. Silently, the light goes out. Something for Moss to think about. He stares. The hallway behind the door is now dark. The door is defi only from his side, by streetlight-spill through the wind Moss stares. He shifts, starts to rise, doesn't. A beat. A report -- not a gunshot, but a stamping sound, followed a pneumatic hiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It brings a dull impact and Moss recoils, hit. He winces, feeling his chest. The door is shuddering creakily in. It is all strange. Moss gropes in his lap and picks somet up. The lock cylinder. The creaking door comes to rest, ajar. Moss fires. The shotgun blast roars in the confined space and for an instant turns the room orange. The chewed-up d wobbles back against the jamb and creakily bounces in aga Moss has already risen and is hoisting the document case.

dialogues.speaker: FROM OUTSIDE HIS WINDOW
dialogues.text: Moss finishes draping his shotgun by its strap across his back and climbs out onto the ledge with the document case He swings the document case out and drops it. The bracketing for the hotel's sign gives Moss a handhold He grabs it as inside the room the door is kicked open. M swings down as, with a muted thump, orange muzzleflash st the room. Moss drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss lands and grabs the document case and straightens. H is at the hotel entrance, standing in the light coming th the etched glass of the double doors. 61

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at his own shadow thrown onto the street. He plu through the doors into the lobby as a gun thumps and crac shot chews the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss hurries across the lobby. A glance to one side: A booted foot sticks out from behind the front desk. Moss slows approaching the stairway. He risks a look arou the stairway wall. Ascending balusters fade off into the blackness of the se story hallway. Moss sags. He looks back across the lobby at the front do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He unhitches his shotgun. He remains still for a moment holding the shotgun, back against the protected side of t wall. He quickly swings out and with shotgun aimed up the stair he crosses to the back lobby. He quietly pushes open the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUTSIDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss emerges into a shallow service alley, dark and dirty He is at a run when we hear soft tock and a garbage can i front of him snaps and wobbles. He turns looking up, backpedaling. Another tock accompani a muzzleflash in a dark second-story window. Moss fires his shotgun: loud. Chips fly off the brickface and the window shatters. Moss rounds the alley corner. He stops and squats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide: dark, deserted downtown Eagle Pass, Moss a lone fig resting at a corner. Close on Moss panting. He takes stock, painfully feeling his upper chest where the lock hit, then touching gingerl at his side, beneath the ribs, newly bloody. He sighs. 62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He listens. No noise. He gets to his feet with the docume case in one hand and shotgun in the other. He waits a bea back against the wall. He swings out and fires the shotgun into the alley and th spins back and runs a short block and rounds the next cor and stops to rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits for his breath to slow. He brings up the shotgun and readies himself. He swings out to look back around the corner. The street is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits, at the ready for whatever might emerge from the alley mouth a short block away. Long beat. Stillness. A panicky thought brings his look and the shotgun swingin back around: the man could round the block the other way. Empty street. Two empty streets: Moss doesn't know which way to cover, which way to go. He stands looking each way, trying to devise a plan. No b for a plan. Quiet hesitation. Now, a sound: engine noise. An old pickup rounds a corner two blocks up. It rattles t him. Moss lowers the shotgun. He keeps it to the hidden side o his body. The pickup dutifully stops at a flashing red traffic ligh It comes on through the intersection. Moss strides out into the street. He swings the shotgun u and gives the driver a raised palm to halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck stops and Moss opens the passenger door and swi the case in and climbs in after. 63

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver, an older man, gapes at him, frightened. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to hurt you. I need you to -- The windshield stars. A quick second round pushes part of the windshield in. Rounds come in without pause, cracking sheet metal, blowi the cab's rear window into the truckbed, twisting the rea view. A round seems to have caught the driver in the throat: a gurgling scream as he claws at his windpipe, blowing out blood. Moss, quicker to react, has already ducked below the dash A snap of the driver's head and a new freshet of blood fr a shot to the head. The screams turn to low gurgles. Moss, jammed almost in to the driver's lap, frantically g for the shift. He throws the pickup into drive and stamps at the acceler driving blind as bullets continue to pour in. He raises his head enough to see his side-view. It shows sluing, bouncing, empty street, rough guide for steering. A tremendous jounce up onto the curb then off it, the dri body swaying in its restraint. The passenger side window shatters: we are passing the gu Now Moss sits up to steer looking out front. Behind him through the shot-out back window the dark street is sudde punctured by muzzleflash. It comes, for the first time, w a report: the low chug of the muted shotgun. Rattle of shot against sheet metal. Moss floors the gas to roar into a turn. The street sweep out of view behind him produces one more chugging muzzlef

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup bounces but Moss, sitting fully up, can now st 64

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes half the length of the block and then yanks the w hard, braking. The pickup smashes a parked car and jacks around to a halt. Moss emerges from the pickup with his shotgun and goes to the sidewalk and backtracks. He covers behind a parked ca He sits leaning back against the car, waiting. His point-of-view: his own reflection in the facing storefront, a lot of the driver's blood on him. He sinks lower. A long beat. Footsteps. They approach without hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gritty boot turn at the corner. The footsteps come clos still. They pass and recede toward the pickup. We cut to Chigurh approaching the pickup, shotgun held at ease across his body. He slows. Moss: he hears the slowing steps. He tightens his grip on his shotgun and tenses. Chigurh: slowing further, he sees: Bloody boot prints outside the passenger door. Moss rises. Chigurh is turning. He dives as, behind him, Moss fires. Shot peppers two parked cars -- the one Moss rammed and t one behind. Chigurh dived between them: hit or not? Moss advances down the middle of the street. He angles hi head: anything under the cars? He fires twice. Buckshot claws up the pavement and the ca bodies and tires, and the cars sink hissing to their rims

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss crosses to the far curb, still advancing. No one beh the cars. 65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up and down the street. Nothing to see. He goes to the pickup truck, driver's side. He opens the door and reaches over the driver's corpse for his lap bel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserted. The pickup truck rattles into frame. Moss emerges. He hoists out the case. He leaves the shotg It is very quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around. The Rio Grande bridge. Moss walks unsteadily toward it, pressing his free hand t his side. A thought stops him. He turns. His bloody boot prints point at him like comic book clues His shoulders sag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minutes later. Moss heads down the right-hand walkway in stockinged feet, boots tucked into his belt. He turns and looks back toward the U.S. side. Empty walkway. He proceeds on. Three youths are approaching from the Mex side. Fart types, they are laughing and walking unsteadil As they approach they gape at Moss, covered with blood. The lead boy, holding a beer, wears a light coat. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you five hundred bucks for your shirt and your coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three boys stare at him. AT LENGTH: 66   YOUTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see the money. Moss unpeels bills from a moist wad. The top one is blood SECOND YOUTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Were you in a car accident? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. YOUTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, lemme have the money. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right here. Give me the coat.  YOUTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme hold the money. Moss does. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the clothes. The youth starts to peel them. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And let me have your beer. YOUTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...How much? SECOND YOUTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian. Give him the beer. MINUTES LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are receding. Moss pours the beer over his head, rubbing blood away. He opens his shirt. He inspects the wounds in his midriff entrance and exit. Pulsing blood laps weakly out. He shru off his shirt, wraps it around his waist and knots it. He starts to put on the new shirt. Something stops him. H pauses. He vomits into the roadbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He straightens slowly and puts on the new shirt. He looks out. 67

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is not yet over the river: wind stirs the cane on the bank. He looks up: Chain-link fence encloses the walkway to a h of about twelve feet, curling inward at the top. He looks down the walkway. The three boys are distant fig He looks up the walkway. A few paces up a light pole stanchion stands flush to the guardrail that separates road and walkway. He goes to the stanchion and uses it to hoist himself ont the guardrail, his free hand holding the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing on top of the curved metal rail and holding the post for balance, he kneebends down and up and heaves the case. It sails clear of the chain-link fence. A short beat and hear a thump. Moss pants for a moment, recovering from the strain of th toss. He eases himself off the guardrail and goes to the fence and looks at the bank below. One gnarled tree stand out in the cane. The case, wherever it landed, is not vis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a lighted guardshack at the end of the walkway. Inside, a uniformed guard. Moss walks unsteadily up. He tilts the beer bottle in sal at the guard. The guard impassively lets him proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In black, an insanely cheerful mariachi song. Fade in on the mariachis. We are looking steeply up at th dutch-angled. They beam down at us, energetically thumpin their oversized guitars and bajo sextos. We boom woozily up and start to un-dutch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverse on Moss struggling to a sitting position on the p bench where he'd been lying. A public square. 68

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the mariachis. Beaming, singing. Their smiles gradually fade. The playing falls off to silence. In the silence, birds chirp. The musicians are looking quizzically down. Moss's arm swings up in the foreground, extending a blood hundred-dollar bill. On Moss. His coat has swung open to expose his bloody mid His look up is glazed. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mariachis stare. Moss waggles the bill. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Medico. Por favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are close on a patch of its front seat. Day. The picku is parked. The piece of upholstery we are looking at has blood soaked into it. On the sound of the door opening we cut wider. We are in parking lot of a Wal-Mart. Chigurh, climbing in, tosses a brown paper bag onto the passenger side. He has a dark to wrapped around one leg. As he slides behind the wheel the wrapped part of his leg slides over the bloodstain.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVELING POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: A small-town main street. We are driving past a pharmacy. Chigurh, looking. He parks. He takes a scissors from the Wal-Mart bag and a box of co He opens the box and cuts a little disc out of the cardbo He takes a new shirt out of the bag and begins to cut thr one sleeve. 69

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING PAST A PARKED CAR
dialogues.text: Chigurh limps toward us. He holds a coat hanger bent stra with the balled-up shirtsleeve hooked at one end. Chigurh arrives, looks up and down the street. He unscrews the gas cap, feeds the coat hanger in to soak the shirt, pulls it back out. He tapes the cardboard disc over the open gas tank. He unhooks the wet shirtsleeve an jams it up over the disk. He lights it and exits.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE PHARMACY
dialogues.text: A beat pulling Chigurh limping up the aisle, and then the car explodes out front. The plate glass storefront blows The few people inside rush out; Chigurh doesn't react. The pharmacy counter in back is deserted. Chigurh lifts a hinged piece of counter to enter and starts looking throu the stock. He pulls out a packet of syringes, Hydrocodone tablets, penicillin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh dumps the pharmaceuticals into the bathroom sink. In the room outside he sits on the bed and takes off his boots. He unknots the towel from around his leg and stand and unbuttons his pants and starts cutting from the crotc down with a heavy scissors. One thigh is a mess of clotte blood and torn fabric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh lowers himself into bath water that quickly turns pink. He laves water over his bloody thigh. There is a da red hole, one half inch across, pulsing blood into the ba water Torn pieces of fabric from his pants are embedded i the bleeding skin.

dialogues.speaker: A SHAVING MIRROR
dialogues.text: We are looking at the wound in a magnifying mirror. Force enter and pluck a tiny piece of blood-soaked fabric from skin. 70  RUNNING WATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bathroom tap. The forceps enter. They are rinsed, shake off. Wider: Chigurh sits on the closed toilet with the mirror sitting on the edge of the tub, angled toward the wound. Chigurh works on cleaning it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main room. The TV is on now. Chigurh enters from the bathroom with his leg bandaged. He sits on the bed and te open the packaging of a syringe. He plunges it into an ampule of penicillin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He injects himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Bell sits writing in a large leatherette checkboo HE PROJECTS: BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything on those vehicles yet? A raised female voice from the front office: VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff I found out everything there was to find. Those vehicles are titled and registered to deceased people. Molly, the secretary, appears at the doorway. VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The owner of that Blazer died twenty years ago. Did you want me to see what I could find out about the Mexican ones? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Lord no. He holds out the checkbook. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This month's checks. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That DEA agent called again. You don't want to talk to him? 71  BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm goin' to try and keep from it as much as I can. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's goin' back out there and he wanted to know if you wanted to go with him. Sheriff Bell is putting things away. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's cordial of him. I guess he can go wherever he wants. He's a certified agent of the United States Government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Could I get you to call Loretta and tell her I've gone to Odessa? goin' to visit with Carla Jean Moss. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes Sheriff. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call Loretta when I get there. I'd call now but she'll want me to come home and I just might. MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to wait til you've quit the building? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do. You don't want to lie without what it's absolutely necessary. Molly trails him into the front office. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What is it that Torbert says? About truth and justice? MOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We dedicate ourselves daily anew. Something like that. 72  BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm goin' to commence dedicatin' myself twice daily. It may come to three times before it's over... A loud truck-by from the street outside. Sheriff Bell's e track the passing vehicle. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanderson outskirts. Sheriff Bell passes a flatbed truck with a flapping tarp briefly blurps his siren to pull it over. He parks on the shoulder in front of the truck and then walks back to the driver who watches his approach, chewing gum with blithe unconcern. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you looked at your load lately?

dialogues.speaker: A MINUTE LATER
dialogues.text: Both men are at the back of the truck. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a damned outrage. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. One of the tiedowns worked lose. Bell whips the tarp back to expose eight corpses wrapped blue sheeting bound with tape. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many did you leave with? The driver is still smiling. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't lost none of 'em, Sheriff. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't you all of took a van out there? 73  DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't have no van with four-wheel drive. Sheriff Bell pulls the tarp down and ties it. The driver watches without helping. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You going to write me up for improperly secured load? Sheriff Bell cinches the knot tight. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get your ass out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss, in bed, stirs at an off screen voice: VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm guessin'... this is not the future you pictured for yourself when you first clapped eyes on that money. Moss blearily focuses on: A fancy crocodile boot. His look rises from the boot, crossed on his visitor's kn up to the man's face. Carson Wells smiles at him from the bedside chair. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Don't worry. I'm not the man that's after you. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I've seen him. Sort of. Wells is surprised. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've seen him. And you're not dead. He nods, impressed. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But that won't last.  MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is he supposed to be, the ultimate bad-ass? 74   WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's how I would describe him. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you describe him? WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'd say... that he doesn't have a sense of humor. His name is Chigurh. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar? WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh. Anton Chigurh. You know how he found you? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how he found me. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called a transponder. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what it is. He won't find me again. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that way. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not any way. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Took me about three hours. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been immobile. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You don't understand. Wells sits back and studies Moss. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What do you do? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm retired. 75  WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a welder. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acetylene? Mig? Tig? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any of it. If it can be welded I can weld it. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cast iron? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean braze. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say braze. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pot metal? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I say? WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you in Nam? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I was in Nam. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So was I. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what does that make me? Your buddy? Wells sits smiling at him. A beat. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. You need to give me the money. I've got no other reason to protect you. 76  MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late. I spent it -- about a million and a half on whores and whiskey and the rest of it I just sort of blew it in. Wells' smile stays in place. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know he's not on his way to Odessa? Moss stares at him. A beat. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would he go to Odessa?  WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To kill your wife. Another beat. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he should be worried. About me. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He isn't. You're not cut out for this. You're just a guy that happened to find those vehicles. Moss doesn't respond. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You didn't take the product, did you? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What product. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heroin. You don't have it. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I don't have it. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You don't. He rises. 77  WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm across the river. At the Hotel Eagle. Carson Wells. Call me when you've had enough. I can even let you keep a little of the money. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was cuttin' deals, why wouldn't I go deal with this guy Chigurh? WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no. No. You don't understand. You can't make a deal with him. Even if you gave him the money he'd still kill you. He's a peculiar man. You could even say that he has principles. Principles that transcend money or drugs or anything like that. He's not like you. He's not even like me. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't talk as much as you, I give him points for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Bell rises from a booth, taking off his hat. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla Jean, I thank you for comin'. She sits. He sits. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know why I did. I told you, I don't know where he is. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't heard from him? CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I ain't. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'? CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not word one. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you tell me if you had? 78  CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know. He don't need any trouble from you. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not me he's in trouble with. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's he in trouble with then? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some pretty bad people. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Llewelyn can take care of hisself. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people will kill him, Carla Jean. They won't quit. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't neither. He never has. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could say that was in his favor. But I have to say I don't think it is. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can take all comers. Bell looks at her. After a beat: BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Charlie Walser? Has the place east of Sanderson? She shakes her head, shrugs. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well you know how they used to slaughter beeves, hit 'em with a maul right here to stun 'em... Indicates between his own eyes. 79  BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and then truss 'em up and slit their throats? Well here Charlie has one trussed up and all set to drain him and the beef comes to. It starts thrashing around, six hundred pounds of very pissed-off livestock if you'll pardon my... Charlie grabs his gun there to shoot the damn thing in the head but what with the swingin' and twistin' it's a glance-shot and ricochets around and comes back hits Charlie in the shoulder. You go see Charlie, he still can't reach up with his right hand for his hat... Point bein', even in the contest between man and cow the issue is not certain. He takes a sip of coffee, leaving room for Carla Jean to argue if inclined. She does not. Sheriff Bell hands a card across. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...When Llewelyn calls, just tell him I can make him safe. She takes the card. Sheriff Bell sips. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Course, they slaughter beeves different now. Use a air gun. Shoots out a rod, about this far into the brain... He holds thumb and forefinger a couple inches apart. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sucks back in. Animal never knows what hit him. Another beat. Carla Jean stares at him. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you tellin' me that, Sheriff? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. My mind wanders. 80

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late Day. Carson Wells grabs a light pole stanchion to hoist himsel onto the guardrail. He stands atop it, eyeing the chain-l fence across the walkway. He climbs down and crosses to the fence and looks down: The brown, sluggish water of the Rio Grande.

dialogues.speaker: LOOKING DOWN THE WALKWAY
dialogues.text: Carson Wells enters frame and recedes down the walkway. When he draws even with the next stanchion he looks down through the fence:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cane on the riverbank, and one gnarled tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twilight. Carson Wells enters the hotel and crosses the l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carson Wells appears around the corner and we pull him as mounts the stairs. When he is about halfway up a figure - focus does not hold him -- rounds the corner behind and silently follows, holding a fat-barreled shotgun loosely his side. After a few steps Carson Wells stops, frowning, cued by w don't know what. Focus drops back as he turns. Chigurh ra the shotgun. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Carson. Let's go to your room.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND HOTEL EAGLE ROOM
dialogues.text: Chigurh sits into a chair drawn up to face the armchair w Carson Wells sits. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have to do this. I'm a daytrader. I could just go home. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I let you do that?  WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where the money is. 81  CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you knew, you would have it with you. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need dark. To get it. I know where it is. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know something better. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where it's going to be.  WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where is that. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be brought to me and placed at my feet. Wells wipes his mouth with his hand. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know to a certainty. Twenty minutes it could be here. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do know to a certainty. And you know what's going to happen now. You should admit your situation. There would be more dignity in it. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to hell. A beat. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something. If the rule you followed brought you to this, of what use was the rule? Another beat. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea how goddamn crazy you are? 82  CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the nature of this conversation? WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean the nature of you. Chigurh looks at him equably. Wells holds his look. WELLS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You can have the money. Anton. The phone rings. Wells looks at the phone. Chigurh hasn't moved. Wells looks at Chigurh, waiting for a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The low chug of the shotgun. Aside from his finger on the trigger, Chigurh hasn't move He sits staring at Wells's remains for a beat. Now his look swings onto the phone. He watches it ring tw more. He picks it up and listens without speaking. After a beat: MOSS'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hello? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? Another beat. MOSS'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Carson Wells there. A longer beat. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in the sense that you mean. Moss doesn't answer. Chigurh gives him a beat, and then: CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You need to come see me. 83

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN HOSPITAL WARD
dialogues.text: We intercut Moss, in his hospital robe, at a public phone the ward. He stands tensed with the phone to his ear. Fin MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who it is. A beat. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You need to talk to me. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need to talk to you. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that you do. Do you know where I'm going? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I care where you're going. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where I'm going? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh cocks his head, noticing something on the floor. adjusts to sit back and raise his boots onto the bed. On the floor where his feet were, blood is pooling out fr Wells's chair. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I know where you are. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Where am I? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in the hospital across the river. But that's not where I'm going. Do you know where I'm going? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know where you're going. 84  CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know she won't be there. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't make any difference where she is. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what're you goin' up there for. A beat. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how this is going to turn out, don't you? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Do you? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. I think you do too. So this is what I'll offer. You bring me the money and I'll let her go. Otherwise she's accountable. The same as you. That's the best deal you're going to get. I won't tell you you can save yourself because you can't. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah I'm goin' to bring you somethin' all right. I've decided to make you a special project of mine. You ain't goin' to have to look for me at all. Moss slams the phone onto its hook, then slams it twice m for good measure. Chigurh, in the hotel room, cradles his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Bell sits at his usual booth, but with an unaccus look: reading glasses. He has been looking at a newspaper but is now peering over his glasses up at Wendell who apparently interrupted his reading. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motel in Del Rio? Wendell nods. 85   WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. None of the three had ID on 'em but they're tellin' me all three is Mexicans. Was Mexicans. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a question. Whether they stopped bein'. And when. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Wendell, did you inquire about the cylinder lock?  WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. It was punched out. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna drive out there? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's the only thing I would've looked for. And it sounds like these boys died of natural causes. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that, Sheriff? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natural to the line of work they was in. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord, Wendell, it's just all-out war. I don't know any other word for it. Who are these folks? I don't know... He rattles the paper. 86  BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Here last week they found this couple out in California they would rent out rooms to old people and then kill em and bury em in the yard and cash their social security checks. They'd torture em first, I don't know why. Maybe their television set was broke. And this went on until, and here I quote... He looks through his glasses at the paper. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..."Neighbors were alerted when a man ran from the premises wearing only a dog collar." You can't make up such a thing as that. I dare you to even try. He peers over his glasses at Wendell who respectfully sha his head and tsks. Sheriff Bell rattles the paper again. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But that's what it took, you'll notice. Get someone's attention. Diggin graves in the back yard didn't bring any. Wendell bites back a smile. Sheriff Bell gazes at him ove his glasses for a long beat, deadpan. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That's all right. I laugh myself sometimes. He goes back to the paper. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...There ain't a whole lot else you can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss, a coat thrown over his hospital robe, is standing b a uniformed INS official on the Rio Grande bridge. The official, who looks like a marine drill instructor, i chewing. He chews for a long beat, staring at Moss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finally spits tobacco juice and pats his lower lip wit handkerchief. 87   OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think gets through this gate into the United States of America? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. American citizens. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some American citizens. Who do you think decides? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do, I reckon. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct. And how do I decide? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask questions. If I get sensible answers then they get to go to America. If I don't get sensible answers they don't. Is there anything about that that you don't understand? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I ask you again how you come to be out here with no clothes. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got an overcoat on. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you jackin' with me? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't jack with me. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.  OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you in the service? 88  MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. I'm a veteran. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nam? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Two tours. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What outfit. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelfth Infantry Batallion. August seventh nineteen and sixty-six to July second nineteen and sixty-eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The official stares at him, chewing, sour. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson! GUARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get someone to help this man. He needs to get into town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk who earlier sold him the boots: CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How those Larries holdin' up? Moss is walking up in his boots and overcoat and hospital robe. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I need everything else. CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get a lot of people come in here with no clothes on? CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir, it's unusual. 89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking across the Rio Grande. Moss appears over t near edge of the river bank, newly clothed, and holding t document case. As he reaches the top of the bank he frowns and twists hi neck, responding to an irritation. He feels around with h free hand inside the back of the shirt collar. A sharp ya His hand comes away with a small tag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The document case is resting on a small foreground counte Moss is at a pay phone, one hand holding the phone to his ear, the other resting on the case. The voice on the phone is old, female, and querulous: VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She don't want to talk to you. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes she does. Put her on. VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what time it is? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what time it is. Don't you hang up this phone. VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her what was going to happen, didn't I. Chapter and verse. I said: This is what will come to pass. And now it has come to pass -- Scuffing sounds, a sharp "Mama!", and then, into the phon CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Llewelyn? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I do?  MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what's goin' on? 90  CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I had the sheriff here from Terrell County -- MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you tell him? CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I know to tell him. You're hurt, ain't you? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you say that? CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hear it in your voice.  MOTHER (DISTANT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is falseness in his voice! MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet me at the Heart of Texas motel in El Paso. I'm gonna give you the money and put you on a plane. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Llewelyn, I ain't gonna leave you in the lurch. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. This works better. With you gone and I don't have the money, he can't touch me. But I can sure touch him. After I find him I'll come and join you. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find who? What am I supposed to do with Mother? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be all right. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be all right? MOTHER (DISTANT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be all right! I've got the cancer!  MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think anybody'll bother her. 91

dialogues.speaker: A LOCK CYLINDER
dialogues.text: It blows in. The hole shows a brightly lit cinderblock wa behind. The door swings open and the air tank is swung in and deposited on carpet. Wider: Chigurh enters the carpeted hallway from the cinderblock stairwell, holding the tricked-out shotgun. The hallway is white wallboard, doors opening off it at l intervals. Chigurh stands still and listens. Nothing but hum of ventilation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks quietly to the one open door twenty feet away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters. The man who hired Carson Wells is behind his desk, in fro of the floor-to-ceiling windows. He looks up from papers, slipping off his reading glasses. On seeing the shotgun h opens a desk drawer and starts to rise. Chung -- the shotgun blast knocks him back. Shot pits but doesn't break the window. A man in a suit rises and turns from the chair opposite t desk, very slowly, as if to advertise that he is not a th Chigurh ignores him and rounds the desk to look at the ma gurgling on the floor. After a beat, still looking down at the man he has shot: CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAN AT CHAIR
dialogues.text: ...Me? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAN AT CHAIR
dialogues.text: Nobody. Accounting. Chigurh finally looks up at him. 92   CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave Acosta's people a receiver.

dialogues.speaker: MAN AT CHAIR
dialogues.text: He feels... he felt... the more people looking... CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's foolish. You pick the one right tool. Chigurh inclines his head toward the pocked glass of the picture window. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...For instance. I used birshot. So as not to blow the window.

dialogues.speaker: MAN AT CHAIR
dialogues.text: I see. He still has not moved, one hand still touching the armre

dialogues.speaker: MAN AT CHAIR
dialogues.text: ...Are you going to shoot me? Chigurh looks at him. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends. Do you see me? The man stares at him for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAN AT CHAIR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EYES IN A REAR-VIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: Eyes in a weathered face shift back and forth between roa and mirror, where they give nodding acknowledgment to the passenger. MOTHER'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I always seen this is what it would come to. Three years ago I pre- visioned it. Wider shows Carla Jean and her mother in the back of the moving cab. 93  CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't even three years we been married. MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three years ago I said them very words. No and Good. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am. MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now here we are. Ninety degree heat. I got the cancer. And look at this. Not even a home to go to. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am. MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're goin' to El Paso Texas. You know how many people I know in El Paso Texas? DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ma'am. She holds up thumb and forefinger curled to make an 0. MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how many. Ninety degree heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab is stopped outside the depot. Carla Jean and her mother and the driver are at the trunk struggling over ba CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it Mama. MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see my Prednizone. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put it in, Mama. MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I didn't see it. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I put it in. That one. You just set there. I'll get tickets and a cart for the bags. 94

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Carla Jean goes to the station a man emerges from a ca pulled up behind. He is a well-dressed Mexican of early m age. MEXICAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need help with the bags, madam? MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well thank god there's one gentleman left in West Texas. Yes thank you. I am old and I am not well. MEXICAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which bus are you taking? MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to El Paso, don't ask me why. Discombobulated by a no-account son-in-law. Thank you. You don't often see a Mexican in a suit. MEXICAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to El Paso? I know it. Where are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla Jean is at a phone booth. After a short wait, a pickup and a filtered: SHERIFF BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla Jean, how are you. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff, was that a true story about Charlie Walser? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Charlie Walser. Oh! Well, I, uh... True story? I couldn't swear to ever detail but... it's certainly true that it is a story. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. Sheriff, can you give me your word on somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF BELL'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: We intercut Sheriff Bell in his office.  BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am? 95   CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I tell you where Llewelyn's headed, you promise it'll be just you goes and talks with him -- you and nobody else? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am, I do. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Llewelyn would never ask for help. He never thinks he needs any. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla Jean, I will not harm your man. And he needs help, whether he knows it or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A driving point-of-view approaching Chigurh, who leans ag his Ramcharger, its hood up, stopped on the shoulder on t opposite side of the road. Reverse shows a man in an El Camino. Chickens in stacked cages squawk and flutter in the bed. The man slows and rolls his window down to lean out. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem there, neighbor. MINUTES LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man has pulled his vehicle over nose-to-nose with Chigurh's. He is rummaging in the car behind the seat. Hi voice comes out muffled: MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that'll suck some power. Over time. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You from around here? The man emerges with jumper cables. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alpine. Born 'n bred. Here ya go. He hands one pair of leads to Chigurh. 96   CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What airport would you use. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Airport or airstrip? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Airport. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- where ya goin'? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just lightin' out for the territories, huh. Brother, I been there... Well... He takes off his hat and draws a sleeve across his brow, thinking. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...There's airstrips. He turns with his pair of leads to clamp them onto his battery. On his back: MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The airport is El Paso. You want some place specific you might could be better off just drivin' to Dallas. Not have to connect. He turns back around to face Chigurh who stands there, st holding his pair of leads. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You gonna clamp them, buddy? Chigurh is looking at him blandly. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you get those chicken crates out of the bed. The man stares at him. MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you talkin' about? 97

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COIN SLOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quarters are fed in. Wider as Chigurh unholsters the wand a self-service car wash. He sprays the spatter-pattern rust-colored stain off the roof of the cab of the El Camino. Water drums as he sprays chicken feathers out of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss is turning the key in his room door, a new vinyl gun bag slung over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the cut the roar of a plane climbing overhead recedes. Out of it, a voice: WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Mr. Sporting Goods. Moss looks. A woman sunbathes at the central court swimming pool. A l of hard light. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey yourself. The woman is pretty in a roadhouse-veteran sort of way. H voice carries a flat echo, slapping off the surface of th pool. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a sport? Moss slings the bag into the room onto the bed and then t and leans against a veranda post. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got beers in my room. Moss holds up his left hand to show the ring. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waitin' for my wife. 98  WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. That's who you keep lookin' out the window for? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else then? MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookin' for what's comin'. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah but no one ever sees that. I like a man that'll tell you he's married.  MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'll like me. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do like you. A beat. Lapping water. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Beer. That's what's comin', I'll bring the ice chest out here. You can stay married. Building jet roar from another climbing plane. MOSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am I know what beer leads to. The woman laughs. Before the plane overwhelms it: WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beer leads to more beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHERIFF BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving. As he drives he refers to one side of the road, a commerc strip, looking for something. We hear the fading roar of large airplane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tock tock of distant gunfire brings his look around. beat. Another tock. The chatter of machine-gun fire. Anot single shot. 99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Bell stamps the accelerator and hits his siren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Point-of-view racing toward the motel: a pickup with a ra of roof lights roars out. Tire squeals, machine-gun chatt and dog barks. The truck turns toward us, then slews arou and speeds away, fishtailing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Point-of-view turning into the central court: a man is crawling on his belly along the veranda toward the street Sheriff Bell skids to a halt and gets out. We hear scream a child crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Bell jogs toward the crawling man, one hand on hi holstered gun. Behind the man on the veranda is his abandoned machine pi He is a Mexican in a guyabera. Sheriff Bell yells at a scared face in a cracked door: BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call police. He is still jogging. A glance to the side: Rough point-of-view of a woman's body, belly-down at the of the pool, head and upper torso in the water. Rough point-of-view forward: an open room door. Booted fe stick out. Sheriff Bell arrives. Moss is face-up, mostly inside the room. The new gun bag is next to him. The gun is in hand. He is still. Voices. Sheriff Bell glances off. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Call your local law enforcement. I'm not on their radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night. The entrance is blocked by police vehicles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People stand around in knots. Sheriff Bell is talking to local sheriff. A door slam attracts his look. 100

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla Jean has gotten out of the far side of a cab. On th near side the driver is leaning in to help her mother out After a couple of rocking attempts she has enough inertia come to her feet outside the vehicle. Carla Jean is advancing slowly toward Sheriff Bell, takin in the scene. Sheriff Bell steps toward her. Her eyes track his hand as he raises it to his hat. He ta it off. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla Jean... CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking down a long corridor flanked by a wall of stainle steel drawers. At the far end stands Bell, hat in hand, staring down into an open drawer just in front of him. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The local sheriff, Roscoe Giddins, stands smoking under t port cochere in front of the hospital. Sheriff Bell emerg from the building. A long beat. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who she is. He puts his hat back on. ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe she was with your boy there. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ID in her room? ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not hardly nothin' in her room. And that establishment was no stickler on registration. Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men start walking. 101  ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...County'll bury her. Here Lies Female, Unknown. Her Number Was Up. A walking beat. ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Buy you a cup of coffee before you drive home?

dialogues.speaker: COFFEE SHOP
dialogues.text: Roscoe and Sheriff Bell face each other over coffee. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No money in his room there?  ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple hundred on his person. Those hombres would've taken the stash. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose. Though they was leavin' in a hurry. ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all the goddamned money, Ed Tom. The money and the drugs. It's just goddamned beyond everything. What is it mean? What is it leading to? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd a told me twenty years ago I'd see children walkin' the streets of our Texas towns with green hair and bones in their noses I just flat out wouldn't of believed you. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signs and wonders. But I think once you stop hearin' sir and madam the rest is soon to follow. ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the tide. It's the dismal tide. It is not the one thing. 102  BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the one thing. I used to think I could at least some way put things right. I don't feel that way no more. A beat. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't know what I do feel like. ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try "old" on for size. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. It may be that. In a nutshell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men are walking out. ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of that explains your man though. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is just a goddamn homicidal lunatic, Ed Tom. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure he's a lunatic. ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what would you call him. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Sometimes I think he's pretty much a ghost. ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's real all right. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that at the Eagle Hotel. It's beyond everything. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he has some hard bark on him. 103  ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That don't hardly say it. He shoots the desk clerk one day, and walks right back in the next and shoots a retired army colonel. They have reached Sheriff Bell's cruiser and he sits in. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to believe. ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strolls right back into a crime scene. Who would do such a thing? How do you defend against it? Roscoe closes the door for Sheriff Bell.  ROSCOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Good trip Ed Tom. I'm sorry we couldn't help your boy. He is walking away. Sheriff Bell sits thinking in the cruiser. He makes no mo for the ignition. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now very late, empty of onlookers and emergency vehicles. Sheriff Bell's cruiser pulls up just inside the courtyard He cuts his engine. Sheriff Bell sits looking at the motel. Very quiet. After a long beat he gets out of the car. He pushes its door shut quietly, with two hands. He looks up the veranda. The one door, most of the way up, has yellow tape across Its loose ends wave in a light breeze. Sheriff Bell looks up the street. Nothing much to attract his attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Bell steps up onto the veranda. He takes slow, qu steps. 104

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We intercut his point-of-view, nearing the door marked by police tape. As he draws close to the door he slows. The yellow tape is about chest high. Above it is the lock cylinder. It has been punched hollow. Sheriff Bell stands staring at the lock. Very quiet. The chick, chick, of the tape-ends against th door frame. Still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSIDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh is still also. Just on the other side of the door he stands holding his shotgun. From inside, the tap of the breeze-blown tape is dulled b perceptible. It counts out beats. Chigurh is also looking at the lock cylinder. The curved brass of its hollow interior holds a reflectio of the motel room exterior. Lights and shapes. The curvat distorts to unrecognizability what is reflected, but we s the color of Sheriff Bell's uniform. The reflection is very still. Then, slow movement. OUTSIDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Bell finishes bringing his hand to his holstered gun. It rests there. Still once again. His point-of-view of the lock. The reflection from here, darker, is hard to read. INSIDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh, still. OUTSIDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Bell, his hand on his holstered gun. A long beat. His hand drops. 105

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He extends one booted toe. He nudges the door inward. As the lock cylinder slowly recedes, reflected shapes scr inside it and slide up its curve. Before the door is full open we cut around: FROM INSIDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door finishes creaking open. Sheriff Bell is a silhou in the doorway. A still beat. At length Sheriff Bell ducks under the chest-high police tape to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The worn carpet has a large dark stain that glistens near the door. Sheriff Bell steps over it, advancing slowly. T room is dimly lit shapes. There is a bathroom door in the depth of the room. Sherif Bell advances toward it. He stops in front of it. He toes the door. It creaks slowly open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bathroom, with no spill light from outside, is pitch black. Sheriff Bell reaches slowly up with one hand. He gropes a the inside wall. The light goes on: bright. White tile. Sheriff Bell squin A beat. He takes a step in. He looks at the small window. He looks at the window's swivel-catch, locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Bell emerges from the bathroom. He sits heavily o the bed. He looks around, not for anything in particular. His look catches on something low, just in front of him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ventilation duct near the baseboard. Its opening is exp its grille lies on the floor before it. 106

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Bell stares. At length he leans forward. He nudges the grille aside. O the floor, a couple of screws. A coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Licking itself on a plank floor, stiffened leg pointing o It suddenly stops and looks up, ears perked. A frozen beat, and then it bolts. The camera booms up to frame the barren west Texas landsc outside the window of this isolated cabin. A pickup truck approaching, trailing dust. The cat reenters frame outsid running across the rutted gravel in front of the house as the pickup slows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellis, an old man in a wheelchair, has one clouded eye. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Min back! Sheriff Bell enters. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know I was here. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else'd be in your truck. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard it? ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard my -- you havin' fun with me? ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What give you that idea. I seen one of the cats heard it. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But -- how'd you know it was mine? 107  ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I deduced it. Once you walked in. Sheriff Bell stares at him. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many a those things you got now? ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cats? Several. Wal. Depends what you mean by got. Some are half-wild, and some are just outlaws. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you been, Ellis? ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lookin' at it. I got to say you look older. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am older. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a letter from your wife. She writes pretty regular, tells me the family news. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't know there was any. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just told me you was quittin'. Sit down. Sheriff Bell lifts an electric percolator off the counter BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want a cup? ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Predate it. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How fresh is this coffee? ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I generally make a fresh pot ever week even if there's some left over. Sheriff Bell pours some.  BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man that shot you died in prison. 108   ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Angola. Yeah. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you a done if he'd been released? ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Nothin'. Wouldn't be no point to it. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm kindly surprised to hear you say that. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the time you spend tryin' to get back what's been took from you there's more goin' out the door. After a while you just try and get a tourniquet on it. He taps a cigarette ash into a mason jar lid on the table front of him. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Your granddad never asked me to sign on as deputy. I done that my own self. Loretta says you're quittin'. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you've circled round. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come're you doin that? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I feel overmatched. A beat. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I always thought when I got older God would sort of come into my life in some way. He didn't. I don't blame him. If I was him I'd have the same opinion about me that he does. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know what he thinks. 109  BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do. A beat. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sent Uncle Mac's badge and his old thumbbuster to the Rangers. For their museum there. Your daddy ever tell you how Uncle Mac come to his reward? Sheriff Bell shrugs. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Shot down on his own porch there in Hudspeth County. There was seven or eight of 'em come to the house. Wantin' this and wantin' that. Mac went back in and got his shotgun but they was way ahead of him. Shot him down in his own doorway. Aunt Ella run out and tried to stop the bleedin'. Him tryin to get hold of the shotgun again. They just set there on their horses watchin' him die. Finally one of 'em says somethin' in Injun and they all turned and left out. Well Mac knew the score even if Aunt Ella didn't. Shot through the left lung and that was that. As they say. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did he die? ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nineteen zero and nine. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean was it right away or in the night or when was it. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe it was that night. She buried him the next mornin'. Diggin' in that hard caliche. A beat. 110  ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What you got ain't nothin' new. This country is hard on people. Hard and crazy. Got the devil in it yet folks never seem to hold it to account. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most don't. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're discouraged. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... discouraged. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't stop what's comin. Ain't all waitin' on you. The two men look at each other. Ellis shakes his head. ELLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That's vanity. After a beat, a fast fade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In black we hear the chink-chink-chink of chain being pla out and the hum of a motor. We cut to a dark foreground shape being lowered in sync w the clinking sound. As it drops it clears a tombstone PROGRESSIVELY REVEALED:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name, Agnes Kracik. Her dates: 1922-1980. The inscription: Beloved Mother. Off that we cut to Carla Jean, standing by in a black dre and dark veil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A parched square of grass in front of the house. A rusty station wagon pulls into the driveway and stops. Carla Je gets out. 111

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla Jean enters and puts on the kettle. She opens the cupboard looking for something.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Carla Jean sits at the kitchen table drinking tea. She lo out the window. Across the street kids are running through a sprinkler th chugs in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEDROOM DOOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Carla Jean enters holding her hat and veil. She throws the light switch and stops, hand frozen, looking into the room. After a beat: CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew this wasn't done with. Chigurh sits at the far end of the room in the late-after shadows. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't got the money. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What little I had is long gone and they's bill aplenty to pay yet. I buried my mother today. I ain't paid for that neither. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't worry about it. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I need to sit down. Chigurh nods at the bed and Carla Jean sits down, hugging her hat and veil. 112  CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You got no cause to hurt me. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But I gave my word. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave your word? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To your husband. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That don't make sense. You gave your word to my husband to kill me? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband had the opportunity to remove you from harm's way. Instead, he used you to try to save himself. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like that. Not like you say. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't say anything. Except it was foreseen. A beat. CARLA JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knowed you was crazy when I saw you settin' there. I knowed exactly what was in store for me. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Things fall into place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minutes later. A beat. The front door swings open and Chigurh emerges. He pauses with one hand on the jamb and looks at the sole each boot in turn. He goes to the pickup in the driveway. 113

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is driving. His point-of-view: coming upon an empty intersection, his light green. Back to Chigurh. He just starts to turn his head to the right. A huge crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh's pickup has been T-boned by an old crate of a pickup. Both vehicles slide to a halt amid broken glass i the middle of the intersection. The windshield of the truck that ran the light is mostly gone. The driver is draped dead on the wheel. After a beat the door of Chigurh's truck is pushed open. staggers out, heavily favoring one leg where the jeans ar shredded and bloody at the thigh. One arm is also bloody hangs limp.
