Blood runs down his face from a scalp wound. He staggers to a lawn and sits. He looks up. Two teenage boys have come out of somewhere. They goggle him. BOY 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister there's a bone stickin' out of your arm. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right. Let me just sit here a minute. BOY 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an ambulance comin. Man over yonder went to call. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. BOY 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right? You got a bone stickin' out of your arm. 114  CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will you take for that shirt? The two boys look at each other. They look back. BOY 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shirt? CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any damn shirt. I need something to wrap around my head and I need a sling for this arm. Boy 2 unbuttons his shirt. BOY 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell mister, I'll give you my shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chigurh uses his teeth to clamp the shirt and rips it and wraps a swatch around his head. He twists the rest of the shirt into a sling and puts the limp arm in. BOY 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that fuckin' bone. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tie this for me. The two boys look at each other. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Just tie it. Boy 2, the one now wearing a T-shirt, ties it. Chigurh pulls a bill clip from his pocket and draws a bil out with his teeth. He holds it out to the boy. BOY 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell mister, I don't mind helpin' somebody out. That's a lot of money. CHIGURH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it. Take it and you didn't see me. I was already gone. BOY 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. Wide on Chigurh limping off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can just hear the boys, small: 115  BOY 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part of that's mine. BOY 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still got your damn shirt. BOY 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ain't what it was for. BOY 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, but I'm still out a shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta pours Sheriff Bell and then herself morning coffe BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll go ridin. LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think. LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't plan your day. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, would you care to join me. LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord no. I'm not retired. A beat. Sheriff Bell sips his coffee. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll help here then. A beat. Loretta takes a sip. LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better not. They both sip. LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...How'd you sleep? 116  BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Had dreams. LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you got time for 'em now. Anything interesting? BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well they always is to the party concerned. LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Tom, I'll be polite. BELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Two of 'em. Both had my father. It's peculiar. I'm older now'n he ever was by twenty years. So in a sense he's the younger man. Anyway, first one I don't remember so well but it was about meetin' him in town somewheres and he give me some money and I think I lost it. The second one, it was like we was both back in older times and I was on horseback goin' through the mountains of a night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut to night, and snow. It is the image that the movie began with. Continuing in voice over: VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...goin' through this pass in the mountains. It was cold and snowin', hard ridin'. Hard country. He rode past me and kept on goin'. Never said nothin' goin' by. He just rode on past and he had his blanket wrapped around him and his head down... The rider passes as described, horses' hooves drumming an scattering divots of earth and snow. 117  VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and when he rode past I seen he was carryin' fire in a horn the way people used to do and I could see the horn from the light inside of it. About the color of the moon. And in the dream I knew that he was goin' on ahead and that he was fixin' to make a fire somewhere out there in all that dark and all that cold, and I knew that whenever I got there he would be there. Out there up ahead. The rider recedes and the image fades, the horn bearing f going last. THE END
